chapter.title: Getting Started
chapter.para: This chapter will introduce you to the CUAE SDK, its relationship with Microsoft .NET, and explore the Cisco Unified Application Designer. After reading this chapter and following the instructions contained within it you should have a functioning CUAE development environment.

section.title: CUAE Development Environment Prerequisites
section.para: The CUAE depends on several external frameworks and applications to do its job. The main components of CUAE are programmed using a combination of C#, Java, and C++. The Application Server is the component that directly affects developers and it is developed using C#. This means that many of the programmatic interfaces are accessed via C#; therefore, a .NET development environment is required to start using the CUAE.

section.title: Installing the .NET Framework SDK and Friends
Mono vs. the Microsoft .NET Framework
section.para: As of CUAE version 2.4 only Microsoft .NET is officially supported. Developers may wish to use Mono when building plug-ins. While this has not explicitly been tested it is possible that it may work. Mono will produce binary compatible assemblies when building in release mode. Your mileage may vary, but adventurous developers may find success if they want to experiment with the Mono implementation of .NET.

The Application Server will always need to be executed using the Microsoft CLR. There are third-party libraries that we leverage that will not run under Mono. Only use Mono for building plug-in assemblies and not for running the Application Server software.

section.title: VMWare Components in the Absence of Communications Manager
Getting to Know the Application Designer
section.para: The Application Designer is the primary development interface of the CUAE. It is an interactive development environment that enables you to build a unified communications application visually and in a workflow type manner. The goal of the Application Designer is to make building the communications portion of your application very easy. It is tightly integrated with the Application Server to enable you to quickly build, deploy, and debug your applications. In this section we will take a brief visual tour of the Application Designer before getting into more detail on how to use it in later chapters.
